awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research Initiation: Market-driven design concept formation in undergraduate engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
Designing successful products requires a balance of many competencies, including technical expertise and business acumen. While undergraduate engineering programs emphasize technical design and analysis, they generally do not adequately teach or discuss marketability, and evidence suggests that engineering students are graduating without a sufficient grasp of the bigger picture of design. At the same time, research in engineering design has resulted in new market-driven design techniques, which provide guidance for design practitioners regarding how to develop products that are both technically sound and marketable. This research project studies the application of market-driven design methods to engineering education, by examining how undergraduate engineering students learn design. It specifically seeks to understand how students' mental models of design develop throughout a third-year design curriculum, which introduces market-driven design concepts through course material and novel interactive tools. By learning more about students' initial mental models of design, as well as how this course influences their conceptions, this project will provide a foundational understanding and recommendations regarding holistic design education for engineers.

To bridge the gap between market-driven design and engineering education research, this proposal explores how students currently understand design as a process before and after exposing them to market-driven design approaches and tools in the context of an engineering design course. The fundamental research questions are: (1) To what extent do undergraduate engineering students' initial conceptions of design account for the market context, such as competition and consumer considerations? (2) In what ways do these design conceptions change after introducing market-driven design techniques and tools in a design course? Data from concept maps (pre- and post-instruction), student reflections on their conceptions of design, and a survey of student perceptions of the course and their understanding of design will be collected and analyzed. This will contribute to a stronger understanding of how students conceptually balance the technical and non-technical elements of design, as well as evidence regarding the value of a constructivism-based educational approach to advancing student understanding of market-driven design. In addition, these research questions will help design researchers to understand the needs of market-driven design methods, as it provides a baseline for how engineers are currently approaching design and how receptive they are to the processes and tools from the research community.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project between Stevens Institute of Technology and Virginia Tech centered on research that bridged the fields of market-driven design and engineering education to advance holistic engineering formation. The project explored undergraduate students' conceptual understandings of product design, and particularly whether they consider the business and market context, such as competition and consumers. Comparisons were drawn between academic majors, and before and after participating in a third-year engineering design course. Student data about their perceptions of product design were collected in the forms of pre- and post-course concept maps, weekly reflections, and post-course surveys, from 295 undergraduate students majoring in mechanical engineering (ME), engineering management (EM), and industrial systems engineering (ISE).

We found that business-related terms were highly prominent in the students' pre-course concept maps. The students generated free-form concept maps starting with the central node "product design," spending 15 minutes expanding with any important concepts that came to mind in relation to the existing nodes. By categorizing all nodes in the concept maps into the three categories of engineering, business, and society, and observing the occurrences of words in each category as a percentage of all words, we found that business-related terms account for approximately 37% of all nodes, whereas engineering-related terms accounted for only a slightly higher proportion at 40%, with the remainder classified as society-related or interdisciplinary. Breaking down the business-related terms into sub-categories, market-focused terms accounted for 14% of all terms. This was examined by program, as the courses for ME and EM/ISE students covered different topics and tools. The pre-course concept maps of ME students contained 36% business terms and 14% market terms, and the EM/ISE students included 41% business terms and 13% market terms. Through this process, we developed a methodology and taxonomy for quantifying student concept maps and classifying terms into thematic categories.

We found that the post-course concept maps showed significant changes in the percentages of terms. Similar analyses of post-course concept maps, which involved an identical prompt but occurred at the end of the course, revealed changes in these percentages of terms. The ME students' post-course concept map contents dropped to 26% business terms and 11% market terms, and the EM/ISE students' concept maps rose to 45% business terms and 21% market terms. There was a strong correlation between the increased terms/themes and their presence in the course syllabi, as the ME course focused more on prototyping, standards, and ethics, whereas the EM/ISE course focused more on market research and business planning.

The student reflections, surveys, and written project reports all exhibit correlations with concept map changes. An analysis of the correlations among data instruments was also performed, finding that all three assignment types (unaided recall reflections, closed-response surveys about learning, and team-generated unaided recall writing about lessons learned) can be meaningful predictors of student conceptual understanding and knowledge development, as measured through concept maps. For the topics that significantly changed in frequency between the pre- and post-course concept maps, all three of these data instruments had positive correlations with these changes. Given that surveys are substantially easier to administer and evaluate than written assignments, instructors should consider the use of surveys on self-reported learning to monitor engagement and conceptual learning.

The overall project findings showed how students from these academic disciplines think about product design, and specifically what types of concepts they consider. The results provide a baseline mapping of these concepts within thematic categories associated with engineering, business, and society, which can support future research and curriculum development in engineering design education. By revealing a stronger understanding of the ways that students conceptualize design in the late stages of an accredited undergraduate engineering program, the findings will impact future teaching and learning to more effectively instill "design in context" skills. This will lead to engineering graduates that begin their careers with a more balanced perspective on design that accounts for not only technical feasibility, but also market success and other important societal factors.
